editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Melina Yeh

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: The Princess: or, love at first sight. A tragicomedy: the scene Naples and Sicily.
Written in Naples by Thomas Killigrew.
Dedicated to his dear niece the lady Anne Wentworth, wife to the lord Lovelace.
London: printed by J. Macock, for Henry Herringman; and are to be sold at his shop at the sign of the Blew-anchor, in the lower walk of the new exchange. 1663.

div.head: The scene in Sicily and Naples.

list.head: Dramatis personae.
list.item: Facertes, late prince, now King of Sicily (By his father's late death in battle) taken prisoner by the Romans.
Lucius, (Under the name of Cilius) brother to Facertes.
Bragadine, son to the governor of Naples.
Terresius, a Sicilian commander, turned pirate.
Tullius, an humorous companion of theirs.
Pimp and bawd of Naples (Bawd's name Olympia.)
Cicilia, sister to Facertes and Lucius.

div.head: The Princess: or, love at first sight.
Act. i. scen. i.
div.stage: Enter two soldiers retiring, beaten in by three others, with them, the lieutenant, holding Sophia in his hand.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Slaves, you have her? you have your throats shaved with a short sword.

sp.speaker: 1 soldier
sp.p: By what title is she yours? We fought for her.

sp.speaker: 2 soldier
sp.p: And by our laws you ought to stand to your lot.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: By what laws? By the Roman law, you rascals? broad-sword-law; besides she looks as if she were sweet and sound, which are things you'll scarce bring a precedent, to prove your interest by.

sp.speaker: 1 soldier
sp.p: We will not quit our shares for words; we have swords.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: And no money; go ye rascals: do you show your teeth? Go, truss, be gone, to the next wood's side, there speed with your ploughs; do you threaten me with your cold iron?

sp.speaker: 1 soldier
sp.p: Your odds makes you presume, but if we meet you alone, o'th' guard.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Then I'll cut thy throat.

sp.speaker: 2 soldier
sp.p: No, we'll spare you that labour, and have yours cut.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Yes, yes, I know thou art good at killing, by attorney.

sp.speaker: 1 soldier
sp.p: 'Sdeath, come away, follow, we shall a have time.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: And that's all, but a wheel and a crowd, that thy end can claim, —
How now? weeping? come, dry, dry; I'll be a father to thee. Art honest?

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Dare not you be honest too?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Honest? Faith, pretty one, he that dares fight is as honest a soldier as needs to be.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: O! ye gods. She lies down

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: They are the prettiest kind of commodities, these women, that a man can deal in, there is nothing like 'em, but ready money.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: Pray, sir, leave talking, and fall to, that we may haveHere they put up their swords.your leavings.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Not a bit, go home to your doll, and fall to your cold meat, friends.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: Hang her, she's old.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Speak reverently of her age, the jade brought great loads to our pleasure, in her youth, and must not be forgotten.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: O but this, sir, has such an excellent face.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Away, you rogues, old chins, and naked chins, boys of the first beard, and find distinction? must your weak stomachs have face-sauce, before you can fall to? the sex (You varlets) was enough, when I was young; and I confess they have been sad days with me, since the face and petticoat came in esteem: look where she lies, (What? weeping, pretty one? now if I should dote in my latter days, and draw in at my eyes a punishment, they say the gods are just, and may, through my doublet, punish the sins of my youth — hum, I'll think no more on't; — faith I must kiss thee. He lies down and she rises.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: O sir, be not so barbarous as to bring those dangers you have beaten hence; why do you lay such rude hands on me? Think you, the innocence of maid and virgin have no power toHe lays hands on her.guard me?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: A maid! by my faith, it's strange, I should ha' judged you at the second age, when women fall; have you no witness of what you say? I have no faith your witness, or I kiss. He still pulls her.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Away, unhand me, and force me not to call down a plague to guard me, scorn not my words, if thou dost this wickedness, thou wilt find the curse of an injured maid strike as sure, as lightning, and as fatal; nor can all thy skill and courage defend thee, but despairs will find thee, and inhabit in thee, till thou art dissolved in the horrors of thy fear. But if this calm, which seems to allayHe lets her go and looks on her.thy troubled blood, be real, upon my knees, I'll fall, and to the gods send my prayers for thee, and they'll prove as great a guard, and thou shalt find this good act interpose between thee and thy greatest dangers.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: By this light she talks unhappily, should I keep her company, I must beg; no more of this discourse, pray.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Let me be safe in my honour, and I'll be silent, and beside the reward that heaven will pay you, my ransom shall be what you'll name.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: You have prevailed, and shall be free from force; but take heed of talking of heaven before these; to tempt them with such promises, is bidding them to their loss; for what can such fellows hope for there, but to become some odd saints without holidays?

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: Lieutenant, you are somewhat free in your opinion of us.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Why, dost thou sweet heart, hope for better? look upon him has he not a promising face? I'll prophecy, Crabb, continue in thy calling, and thou art safe, for thou hast endeavoured long, and I fear not, but hast made good friends below, and mayst be of a good rank in hell.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: Faith, lieutenant, methinks , you spurred fairly forwards, and, upon my conscience, will be richly damned.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Who I? Faith and troth I think I shall, and yet, whileShakes his purse.this lasts, I have good hopes; for I am of opinion, no man is damned that has money in his purse; nor do I see how poor folks can be saved; what noise is that?

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: I hear our captain's voice.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Away, take her to my quarter, and, upon your lives, no insolence; pray step off with them, till I see what occasions this noise.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.l: I will go, but if this be treachery
Know, though 'tis easy to abuse the gods,
Yet it is heavy for to bear their rods.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Away, you are safe.

div.head: Act. i. scen. ii.
div.stage: Enter captain and soldiers, with the Romans bound, that were taken with Sophia.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: Sir, these are some poor rogues.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Hang 'em then for being poor.

sp.speaker: 1. Roman.
sp.p: Cannot our prayers find thy mercy?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: A pox upon your prayers, they could not protect thee; hang 'em I say.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Hold sir, mistake not these men, for, if I guess right, they are no beggars.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Bring the torture then.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: I believe, I know a way to gain the truth without a rack: there is a wench —

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Ay, what became of her?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: She's in my power, and talks not like a beggar; by this day, she threatened me, and frighted me from my pleasure, she proffered a ransom too, things that beggars never dream on.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Where is she? We will load her with chains, till they confess.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p:
Patience a little, and I'll instruct you; do but threaten
to kiss her, (You understand me) and, upon my life, she'll tell all.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: To the dungeon then with these, and fetch her; but dost thou hear, lieutenant, is she likely? is it a handsome wench? dost thou see ready money in her face?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: O, 'tis a proper wench, and bravely built, such eyes, so black, so great, of a beauty that is currant everywhere , than her cheeks, and such lips; ha! by this hand I could ha' dwelled for ever there.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: She came luckily for this mart; what became o'th boys we took a swimming in Baio?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: They are safe, and will be ready for the same freight.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: And all will scarce quit cost.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Faith captain, we have no luck of late, our old soldiers are immortal too, they will not die, there comes no profit that way of late; when the Moor was captain, in his years there fell as many of those rotten plums, as were worth ten thousand drachms.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: And since my reign, I cannot count a thousand. The young Cicilian, the bold Cilius, is returned too, and now I have no hope to continue another year.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Which? he that was the prisoner?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Yes, the same, his hopes stand fair for the next election, nor shall I envy him if he gain it, for it's a gallant fellow, and indeed ought to command here.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Faith captain, a competent ill nature (I thank the gods) I have gained in the service, and to me 'tis indifferent who is captain, for I must be lieutenant still, till my lot falls, and yet I have so much gratitude as to be angry with old Tullius.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Why dost thou blame a man for desiring to live?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: By my faith, when a man desires it so unreasonably, I do; he knows he cannot live, and yet he has not so much good nature as to die; what if he may linger out this month? he'll die the next, and then your reign expires.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Marry, and the villain is rich, and 'twere not amiss to be his heir.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: If he die in time; but if he live he will not be worth one drachma; for since they told him he could not escape, the slave that grudged himself bread before eats gold now, and considering you are his heir, it is your gold he eats; would I had such title to his estate, by this light, I'd choke him, slave.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Thou art in the right, if he die this month, I am his heir, by the laws of our band, if next, he that succeeds; and I am certain, he made his fortune under me.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Why I, there's the point, faith captain, if you please, I'll go speak with him, and try what good nature will do, it may be he'll hear reason, I'll urge how much he is bound to you.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Thou mayst go, but I'm afraid it will be lost labour.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: A party of Romans taken, where? guide my hate, that with fatal wounds I may empty their proud veins.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: How now Cilius, what rage is this?

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: O Teresius, can you be content, because our persons lie hidden, to let our shames continue visible, and thus sleep out the sufferings of our country? I passed o'er her bosom in my journey, oh! had you, with me, seen the general calamities she groans under, ruined even to a chaos, and the wretched people, grown so degenerate in their sufferings, that they begin, with joy, to obey the insulting conqueror.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: It is wisdom now to obey.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: Wisdom? Is Teresius grown so tame, to think so? let the dogs, not Cilius, practise it.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Why thus impatient?

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: Our country and our miseries call for our swords to protect her, and to see you thus tame makes me so.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: This rage serves her as little — and 'tis now in vain to attempt their ruin, whose conquest has taken such firm root.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: Those that bled in the last battle thought not so.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: To what rash attempts would your rage guide you! is the sad issue of that day no example which our brave prince Facertes was forced to survive, and adorn their triumphs? But that being passed, he had died upon the hook, nor could the intercession of Virgilius letters have deferred the doom, though he bestrid him in the heat of battle, had not the far-famed Sophia, in his approaching fate, called to mind that which he (Though an enemy) protected her brother from, and in the instant kneeled and embraced Caesar's knees, divinely pleading, Pallas inspired her, and with her own beauties clothed the virgin, and with such power the goddess moved in her, that when Caesar gazed upon her blue eyes he left to be Caesar, and rather obeyed then granted, and to be her father could scarce secure him from being fettered with those white wrists which circled his imperial knees.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: Was Virgilius then in the power of Facertes, that day, and did he let him escape, did he fawn upon the roman?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: It was but to return the piety Virgilius showed his foster-father, who (You know) protected him in that sad day our King was slain, and, by his power, he grew able to give that last blow for his country's freedom, which when the aged Nigro saw inclining to the Romans, covetous to have his age set in some glorious act, he charged the youthful Virgilius, but o'er loaded with courage, his silver hairs sunk under the roman, whose piety bestrid him like his father, vowing to sacrifice upon that breast, sooner than wound it.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: 'Twas done like the son of the first Julius; these are degenerate, and succeed only in the others fortune, not his merit, yet — had I been by —

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: What could your single arm have done?

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: Killed Virgilius, in revenge of the rape the Roman ploughs has made upon my mother's womb. For other parent than my country, I yet could never find. Oh! that I had been that day with the brave Facertes, who knows but I might have digged a glorious monument in some lucky wound, given in the face of this admired Virgilius, and after such a fortune, I could have smiled, and, unshook, stepped into my grey. Or if slaved, such bold truths I would have uttered, they should not have destroyed me for cold example, but rather because Rome durst not let me live. And yet I beg if there be any power favourable to Cilius, let it set within my swords reach this Virgilius, this King of men, this Sicilian scourge, that makes us kneel and kiss our afflictions; then, then, Teresius, thou shalt see, how with this sword I'll hunt his pale soul to her last home.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: 'Tis a gallant youth, how his spirit boils, to be in action.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: If I be chose captain of our band, by all our bondaged gods, in some disguise, I'll see that Rome, I will Teresius, and with a few wounds well dealt, gather a numerous revenge; say, would not you obey, if I command, to join in such a sacrifice, where, to fall, the offering is as glorious, as to stand the priest, and such attempts are becoming sacrifice for men, let women incense burn, it is properer for us to expiate with wounds, than prayer or fasting, and had those we vainly dealt in sacrifice been given upon our enemies, our herds had now been fair, and Rome ashes.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: May all thy thoughts prove prophetic, and here I vow to obey whate'er thou enjoinest. — though it be not safe to let thee know the reason, nor the interest thou hast in thy country's sufferings.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Sir, will you come to the examination, the prisoners are at the quarters.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: What prisoners?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: The Romans.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: Why are they not staked?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: There's a woman amongst 'em.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: You will not stake her, will you?

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: No, I make no war with women.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: If she must die, I beg the staking of her.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: What is she?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: More than young, and handsome, and one that talks unhappily; I know not —

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: I'll go see her; captain, I'll meet you at the oak.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I'll to my quarter, and attend you.

sp.speaker: Virgil.
sp.p: O let me stretch myself, and thus enlarged possess my joys; for know, my longing soul made a crown a burden, and with greater joy I have put off an empire, than thou thy chains; and now transported with my hopes, the bird that from the cage is flown, and broke that prison, where she was wont to mourn, and sings all tunes at once, that bird, I say, cuts not the yielding air with more joyful freedom, than I, to find myself, and delivered from that imprisoning state.

sp.speaker: Facer.
sp.p: Sir, thus far I have obeyed your commands, which enjoined me to accompany you from Gallia hither: but what your design should be, that makes you thus, with joy, quit your command there, and be pleased to find yourself unknown and hid in a disguise at Naples, I cannot guess, nor shall I be so rude to ask; for sure if it were fit I knew it, you, that dare trust your sleeping self in my power, would not hide it from me.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Does not my friend guess, whither I am bound?

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Not the particular; but I am certain 'tis some great design, to conquer which, you thus in ambush lay the great virgillius.

sp.speaker: Virgil.
sp.p: The body was made the souls slave, and now but serves her to advance my ends; nor is my mind less, or thoughts more subject to fear, then when an army compassed me.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Sir, that you are alone makes you not less in my esteem; for it is not your power I admire, (The loss of mine own tells me, that's mortal) but your mind; which, when Virgilius is nothing but what my memory gives life to, will make me worship his monument.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: No more, prince Facertes, my friend, and to confirm him take a secret, by which I'll bind him to me for ever; for secrets have stronger ties than love, or vows; for whilst thou hast honour that binds thee, the other may by mistake or passion (Which friendship's self is subject to) fall even to hate.

sp.speaker: Facertes.
sp.p: Then, when I have honour, I shall know your design.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: When thou hast! O Facertes, my friend, it was born with thee; and where it is not natural, swords cannot acquire it; take therefore into thy heart all the secrets of mine, and in a word, all my hopes, and all my fears, Cicilia.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: What of her, sir?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: She is all my hopes, all my wishes, and all my fears; and if she smile, I am fortunate: for know, my journey is to lay at her feet myself, and all that conquest gave me. What thinks Facertes? will she accept it, and not destroy the destroyer? For nothing can be conquest, where she suffered, but height of murder.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p:
What, do I hear my prayers forestalled, and those joys our country ought to sacrifice for, offered to us? I hope Virgilius
is not still pleased to triumph o'er our miseries, and throw a scorn upon that, which he thought worthy of his sword?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Have you not yet forgiven what was my fate? while these thoughts dwell in thee, I must not hope Facertes will join the power of a brother to assist my wishes.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: If you are real, you shall tread upon my neck, but if this be scorn, 'tis so unlike my friend, and so unbecoming the brave Virgilius, that I should not fear to call him enemy, nor despair his conquest.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Real, Facertes! why when have I jested with my friend? Real? yes, as thy vows to Sophia. Never start, nor put on amazement, was I less worthy of a trust, because thou thoughtest me worthy to have been thy enemy? call me friend, and hide thy love? Either thou hast not found the knowledge, or lost the value of thy friend: I tell prince Facertes, she, whom he sacrificeth to, has greater ties upon me as friend then sister.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: That I do love the divine Sophia, witness my part of heaven, which is all thou hast left me to swear by; but if thou hast gained the knowledge of that secret, by jealous guesses, purchased treachery, or with thy power hast wrought upon her sex to betray her innocent affection, draw thy sword, for, by all our gods, noFacertes draws his sword. distance, as enemy, nor nearness of friendship shall divide us, or secure thee from my vengeance.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: I am innocent, and you are angry; here read that, it will tell you, you have injured me. He gives Facertes a letter.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Can Virgilius pardon me, and still have patience to learn me how to conquer nations first, and then myself, by his great example?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p:
Your friendship I shall never decline; and if Sophia be just, you have a warrant for you faith of mine. When I went for Gallia to take command of those legions there, at parting, we fell into discourse of you, and the never-enough-admired Cicilia, whose beauties and virtues she always mentioned with admiration: I confessed to her, that her former descriptions had engaged my affections to your sister's fame so much, that I was resolved, in some disguise, to see her. O'erjoyed with this news, she recommended you to me for a guide, and though I ever admired the honour I found in Facertes, yet I confess, I made a little stop ere I resolved to put myself in the power of one, whom I had tempted with such a ruin, as obeying my father's injunctions, had made me lay upon your suffering country; to remove which doubt she blushed out this secret; I asked her then, why she suffered thee to be led in triumph? she said, she pleaded against it, what she durst, and had she loved less, she could have said more, but seeing her own guilt, she feared it might have been trouble to all: now if this truth can satisfy Facertes, that I have not wronged him, and now I beg, he'll give me leave to return his vows, to Cicilia; and now I conjure thee by that power which thou hast given her, in Sophia's name, here to bury all thy fears, all thy anger, all remembrance that I was a misfortune to thee, in return of which upon thy breast, the
altar of friendship, I'll lay mine a sacrifice, and vow myself to fair Cicilia, and her country, a constant friend.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Oh! sir, the joys you load your slave with, I wish you may find, when you sigh under such a pleasing burden, as the enjoying all your wishes brings. And if my prayers be prosperous, Virgilius will prove our physician, and the wounds he gave, but prescriptions, and we have bled for our health only.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: From hence then, I'll count my conquest over Facertes, and think I have brought more strength to our empire, by his friendship, than his country.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: If you intend a sudden journey, give me leave to furnish you with a galley, I have some acquaintance in the town; I'll dispatch, and meet you presently upon the mould: will you not send, to see whether your sister be arrived at Baio?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Yes, and we'll touch there, as we go.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: When I kissed her hands, to go for Gallia, she said, she was immediately to retire to Baio.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: We need not bid each other haste, since love's our guide.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Hitherto, fair one, your beauty has preserved you; but let not your pride teach you, from success, to scorn a proffered love, that brings safety with it; for me, I confess I durst not enter where that beauty guarded; there was something in that angel from that stroke me, and I boast a wound received from you, more than a conquest over another.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: This act shows you truly valiant, and this fear, you pay the gods, is courage: fools and cowards only dare their power, and you shall find success and conquest still await you, when you strike not against them; and my prayers shall invert the kind of this offering, and make a sacrifice of that which is duty: and you shall receive a reward for paying, as if you had given hecatombs.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Faith, pretty one, I am pleased with what you say, though I understand it not, pray, what kind of place is yours, in heaven? By this hand, I think she keeps the sweetmeats, or else, is woman butler there.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Alas, sir, I am so mortal, I am subject to you: for heaven, I know it not, but by faith, and that tells me, when I am injured, my curses wound, and when served, my prayers heal.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Then you have nothing to show, under the hands of those, what do ye call 'em? those gods?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Nothing, but the examples of their justice; which, with punishment, visit the wicked.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p:
Now do I begin to find, I was a fool, and this wench a talker, by this hand I thought she had had some of the gods in liveries, at her elbow, and there's no such thing, all is but a dream;He offers to kiss her.
But I'll be no longer fooled by my fears. Faith, pretty one, let's try whether they be at leisure, or no; or if they be, they cannot have the face to punish us for those faults they were so subject to themselves.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: They are in a sad condition, that instead of repentance, seek examples for their sins; and the second is worse than the first; as insolence, is worse than weakness: why do you lay such rude hands upon me, you will not destroy what you have built?

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: Wait without.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Are you there? Then I am prevented, a pox upon myCilius gazes upon her. tender nature, this it is to be ignorantly wicked, and subject to fits of conscience.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: Lieutenant, is that the prisoner, you spoke of?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: Thou liest.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: I tell thee, it's false, it's here the prisoner stands. Touches himself.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: That's she, I spoke of.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: Leave us then.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Ye gods, new miseries.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Why so; there's but three steps to a woman's bed, liking, alone, and consent. Two of them he has passed already, if she consent, I would he might pay her: look how they gaze, this is love, and I have bought wit, but if a long staff keep me from the next, let 'em geld me.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: Fair one, what country boasts these beauties?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Sir, I can answer for myself, but for those beauties, you speak of, let them find a friend, I have misfortunes enough to busy my time, and I find it business enough to make it appear fit to live: the thoughts of beauty, are fit for those that have fortunes like their faces, and if mine be like my fortune, (As a friend I counsel you) not to let your eyes dwell longer here, for it's a dangerous habitation, not safe to me, that am native there, and I should mourn more for your dangers, than mine own, for I know how to be just, but I could never find, how to be fortunate.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: A curse find him, and all passed plagues be but stored for him, that would seek to deface that temple, and whate'er your modesty can urge. — thus I'll pay my duty, for I know, such aHe kneels to her.worship can be no new thing to the deity, that's shrouded in their eyes.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: If you kneel, I must kneel too, for the guilt is no less to take a worship where it is not due, than to pay it. She kneels likewise.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: But if the guilt be equal, pray refuse not to receive an unfeigned one.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: I dare not rise, while you kneel; for although the fault be equal, yet civility makes this fitter. They both rise.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p:
I'll not dispute; for know, should you command, through sin, I'd serve you; and therefore you may be confident, I'll obey you, when you command me shun it; and here, with shame, I confess, I came prepared with lust, hungry with sin, and looked to
have met a sacrifice to me. — but I have found the power, and now return as from the altar, struck with holy despairs, and shall feed on what I have already fed my eyes and ears with.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Sir, I find there's honour in your breast, but I fear that safety dwells not everywhere ; for the soldier that you found with me, repents him of the good that saved me.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: He dares as soon suck in a pestilence, as breathe on that air, I frown in; he is my slave, and to my will his fate is tied, if he dares breath ought but obedience, 'tis his own sentence; say, fairest, shall he live, by our gods (But to serve you) he should not. What, ho! Lieutenant, sirrah, what was it you said, to disturb this calm.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Faith little sir, something that tended to the use of handsome women.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: Slave, didst thou look upon her, and not kneel? by herself, I swear (Purer then which our temples show nothing) if any act or word of thine shall henceforth pay less reverence here, then at the altar, thou art earth; mark me; this shall wound thee into earth. He lays hand on his sword.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Sir it shall, and I'll call it justice, death has taken six I think, and is drunk with her beauty, a pox upon me: I must be praising her forsooth.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Sir, you need not threaten, the reward is not worth the hazard, and I am safe.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: The reward! o, that it were to be purchased at the rate of kingdoms, than the sword might gather those beauties! but they are neither within the compass of conquering, nor dying for, else I durst say, after all my wounds and triumphs, see your slave; but now I am lost in my despairs.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Sir, truth has such affinity with truth, that I can scarce hide one from you, which I fear will be displeasing.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: To serve you, is the first thoughts of my heart, and since I cannot, myself be happy, let me contribute my power to make you so; dare you tell me who you are?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: A vow forbids me.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: Sir, the captain expects you.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: Me? I'll wait him presently: lieutenant, see you cherish your first act, and with honour treat this lady, and you shall command me; your pardon, fair one, our captain commands me hence, but you shall be safe from all dangers, but what your sadness brings, and I shall be proud to be called yours, though despised.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Witness heaven, all that honour can spare me is yours; and therefore I beg you will not injure me, to say I despise you: when we have not, we cannot pay, and I shall mourn to think I must die your debtor.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: Madam, but I can admire and sacrifice in thoughts, pray command me to do something for you, o! that these five tedious days were wasted, that, without a treachery, I might say, you are free, but if you can find a strength to resist these miseries, till then, by our gods, you are as free as they, and as readily I'll obey you.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Sir, your first bounties make me happy; and since I have your protection for my honour, all the rest, when they are blown over, bring but a pleasure in the relation.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: I must go — there is a necessity that forces me to obey, I cannot else command your safety. — lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: Need I say again, protect this lady?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: No sir, by this hand, he hath gelt me with a look, madam, will it please you to walk?

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Yes sir, I'll follow you, and I hope I shall not be ashamed to follow my Facertes, whose soul, I think, holds intelligence with this soldier; and were it not that I been accustomed to see such virtue, this would start me.

div.head: Act. ii. scen. i.
div.stage: Enter Nigro wounded, and Cicilia holding him by the arm.

sp.speaker: Nigro.
sp.p: Fly, o fly, and save yourself, madam, this piety will give wings to your innocence; for it is just, ye powers,A noise of fighting within.by miracle, to save that miracle.

sp.speaker: Cicilia.
sp.p: No father, the fears and niceties of our sex I have long since banished hence; and so many have been my days of mourning, that I thought not to have shed a tear for any new misery; but this is a loss I could not foresee, and by surprise this grief has got into my heart, look, if I have not tears left. — oh! ye heavens, where is that justice and mercy we sacrifice to? Why were you absent when his sword struck in your own cause? He faints. Wounds, and age! There is a kind of sacrilege in this murder, and I could be wicked in my anger, to see his faithful youth preserved thus to a punishment, and, instead of a reward, see him pursued like the wicked, and his age set in blood.

sp.speaker: Nigro.
sp.p:
O excellent maid! let not my ruin beget faults in thee;A noise within.nor do thou thus repine at the last and greatest of my honours; is it not better to sink thus, then blushing say I surfeited, or go shaking out with an ague, like a coward schoolboy, to my grave! Fairest, I have been bred a soldier; and had it been as noble to yield as conquer, I could have died as easily, as killed. — your hand, madam, for I find I faint, why should I grieve to die, that have this to lay me in the earth! O weep not, by this last smile I conjure you, weep not; but let your sadness die, and my memory live; for witness that power, to whom I am now offering myself, as my last sacrifice, I have all that dying Nigro could wish; am I not blessed with my country's cause to die in, while a Princess mourns at my funeral, and an angel virgin is
He swounds. She looks sadly upon him.
They seize Cicilia.sent to close mine eyes.

sp.speaker: Cicilia.
sp.p: He's dead. —

div.stage: Enter the viceroy and soldiers, the viceroy is wounded and taken, he falls.

sp.speaker: 1. Soldier
sp.p: Hands off, this is my prisoner.

sp.speaker: 2. Soldier
sp.p: She's finely built, I think she was furnished for the mart.

sp.speaker: Crabb.
sp.p: I'll have her clothes, I spied them first.

sp.speaker: 1. Soldier
sp.p: I'll have her, and let whose will take the rest; I desire but to be lost in the wood with her, for a night, and let him take her that finds her in the morning.

sp.speaker: 2. Soldier
sp.p: He were a bold fellow, that would come after thee.

sp.speaker: Crabb.
sp.p: Come, leave this squabbling, lest the lieutenant come, and than you get not a bit.

sp.speaker: 1. Soldier
sp.p: Faith, and thou art in the right, and I confess I would be glad to find a way to be revenged for the last he took from us.

sp.speaker: 3. Soldier
sp.p: I could tell you how to do it, and profitably too, if you would all take my counsel.

sp.speaker: 2. Soldier
sp.p: Propose, propose.

sp.speaker: 3. Soldier
sp.p: Then quit your thoughts of this dainty bit, and let's away with her, and the rest, to Naples, and sell 'em, this finePoints to Cicilia.thing shall yield money, that will buy wine, and wenches, that bring no fears along with 'em; this gay thing, should we touch her forbidden fruit, we were damned; and we are sure, our lieutenant will pursue us with fire and sword.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Agreed, agreed.

sp.speaker: 3. Soldier
sp.p: Thus rigged then, let's away, but we had best leave one to tell our captain we are put to sea, in pursuit of a galley that bore the Roman eagle, that will take off suspicion while we are absent; then we may return, and say, they out sailed us.

sp.speaker: 2. Soldier
sp.p: I'll stay, but remember my share.

sp.speaker: 3. Soldier
sp.p: What, dost thou think we are thieves amongst ourselves? Come, help draw these dead bodies into the wood, we'll bury them when we return.

sp.speaker: 1. Soldier
sp.p: Bring her away too, and take care of her, lest she spoil herself, and undo our market.

sp.speaker: 3. Soldier
sp.p: Come, pretty one. — nay, you must part. She sits by the body of Nigro all this while.

sp.speaker: Cicilia.
sp.p: Fool's, you pull on your fates, and labour to steal that vengeance that would find you were you hidden in the earth; and my prophetic soul tells me, I go but to see you punished.

sp.speaker: 1. Soldier
sp.p: What says she?

sp.speaker: 2. Soldier
sp.p: I know not what she says, but I hope she lies; do you hear, what kind of women are your witches?

sp.speaker: 1. Soldier
sp.p: A pox, they are old, come mistress, dangers and handsome women dwell not together; if they do, let me fall into them. —

div.head: Act. ii. scen. i.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: What were those Romans, that fell to my share?

sp.speaker: Crabb.
sp.p: They were taken when the pretty wench was taken, that Cilius would have had.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Did you deliver 'em to the lieutenant, and bid him come hither with his account?

sp.speaker: Crabb.
sp.p: I left 'em there, and bid him come to your worship, but I found him a little troubled, he had been at the soldiers; but the fellow is wilful.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: But I have taken an order to bring him to reason.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Whoreson clown, refuse to pledge me or die; rascal, neither drink, nor die. umh.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: How now, lieutenant, what passion's this?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Rogue, refuse to die, or drink my captain's health, at my suit, and yet confess a beer-glass would kill him.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Oh! is that the cause?

sp.speaker: Crabb.
sp.p: I'll swear, he is very unreasonable.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: And ought to be put to death, for refusing a health.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: That was spoke like my captain, and I'll kiss his foot, nay, nay, do not hold me, let me go, let me go, I say, that I may kneel, and wish thou mayst live, till I refuse a beer-glass.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: What hast thou there?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: A julip. He has a little bottle in his hand.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: What are the ingredients?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Simple aquafortis, to warm his stomach. Dog, offer to live, when wine is a poison to him?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: You shall not poison him.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: No, I'll get his doctor to prescribe it, and then 'tis physic.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: No, no poison.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Then he'll live.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: No I have prevented his living, for I was afraid thou wouldst not succeed. Thou hast no oratory, thou canst not persuade, then, thou art so subject to choler; did you mark the old woman you met at my quarter? it was his wife. In six words, I made a price with her, to kill him, without any of the difficulties you found in persuading him.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Captain, you are weak, captain; I not eloquent? your argument is weak; death, do you think 'tis no more to persuade one to die, than to hire another to kill him.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Stand fair, and I'll confute you. Crabb.

sp.speaker: Crabb.
sp.p: Lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: What wilt thou give me to kill him.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Come, leave your fooling, and give me your account.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p:
Am I eloquent then?
Lieu. offers to draw his sword.
The lieu. pulls out a piece of dirty paper, and gives it him.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Yes, yes, give me your account, and I'll believe you eloquent, what's this?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Your account.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: My account?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Yes, and an eloquent account.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: What's here? paid, lent, given, and rests due; faith it's an eloquent account indeed: but lieutenant, is this all?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: All? why would you have more?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Kind lieutenant, I would have an account.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Why have you not an account? All is but this over and over; but if you'll give it me again, you shall have a longer bill.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: But lieutenant, eloquent lieutenant, is that all that's left of my four thousand sestertia.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Why, what account should I make you? would you not pay what you owe? and lend a good fellow that drinks fair; or is your charity dead to pretty sinners in their necessity, and militant in the world?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: But grant these uses, what is the sum? what paid, what lent?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Why, what you will.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Very good. But what means this, rests due, of whom must I inquire for that?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Of me Torrafuco, lodging at the sign of the lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Crabb, knock, and if the party be within, tell him, I would speak with him, and require an account of certain living creatures that were given to his trust, women and children.

sp.speaker: Crabb.
sp.p: They, sir, are increased, the Moor has a calf running by her side, of his own getting, the other Barbary is with foal to; and she that you sent today had like to have been leaped in his collar.

sp.speaker: 2 soldier
sp.p: The alarm, sir, is given, from the shore, and the lion is in chase of a galley that bears the Roman eagle, and Cilius waits directions at your quarter.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Tell him, we come, and, do you hear, get the leopard's gang ready; what will my careful steward do, visit the sick? Pray, let the prisoners be bathed first, and well fed, against the mart.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Crabb.

sp.speaker: Crabb.
sp.p: Here, noble lieutenant, I am always ready to serve. — when he is in this humour I cleanse his pockets, and that's my revenue. Aside.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Crabb, talking is not good for me when this fit is upon me; for I find, I am subject to grow angry, weak and drowsy.

sp.speaker: Crabb.
sp.p: Therefore you must master your passion, at first, ere it grow upon you; but there is no speaking to you when you are in an argument.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: I find thee an able man, and therefore I'll lean upon thee: what's that, Crabb?

sp.speaker: Crabb.
sp.p: What's what, sir?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: I felt a live thing in my pocket, Crabb. Crabb, picks his pocket as he leans on him, he finds his hand in his pocket.

sp.speaker: Crabb.
sp.p: It may be your worship's breeches are torn.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: I will reward thy faith with a trust, Crabb, here, to let thee see, how dear thou art to me, keep my tobacco-box.

sp.speaker: Crabb.
sp.p: Noble lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: No thanks, but help to lay me down behind some tree, in the shade.

sp.speaker: Crabb.
sp.p: Your worship's head is full. — I could have gelt him, the slave has drunk himself stiff.

div.stage: [enter Crabb again with his money in his hat.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Crabb, Crabb. Lieu. as he lies holds up the curtain, and calls Crabb.

sp.speaker: Crabb.
sp.p: Here, here.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Prithee stick a bough for a mark, that thou mayst find me again, lest I be lost in my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Crabb.
sp.p: I shall, I shall.

div.head: Act. ii. scen. ii.
div.stage: Enter at one door the soldiers, with Cicilia and the rest of the prisoners, to be sold; at the other door a pimp, and a she bawd.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Captain, a word with you, I have viewed your ware, but is there any special piece amongst 'em?

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: As you see; they are young, and sound.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Will you give a trial?

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: With the eye, and the tongue, question, or search them, nothing else.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Not a little freedom alone? you were not wont to be thus hard.

sp.speaker: 3 soldier
sp.p: Faith, we have had no luck of late, mistress, this is the first mart we have made this month.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: And you come to our house, it shall cost you nothing.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: At what price do you hold that fine thing?

sp.speaker: 1 soldier
sp.p: That? it is the cream of our mart, she will cost two thousand sestertia.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Is she a maid?

sp.speaker: 1 soldier
sp.p: I'll warrant that, if I sell her.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Come, a thousand is fair, and take you the profit of the first night.

sp.speaker: 1 soldier
sp.p: No, altogether, or nothing, view her, she is worth the money naked.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: But, my friend, I hope you have tried yourself, ere now? are you fruitful? She speaks to one of the slaves.

sp.speaker: Slave.
sp.p: Yes, mistress, and if you agree upon the price, you shall find me a faithful servant; and for the sport, if I raise you not a crop from the common, geld me.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Geld thee? Marry God forbid man; I'll lame thee first, art sound too? else I may live to curse your doings.

sp.speaker: Slave.
sp.p: Sound as a bell, and as ever you hope to be satisfied, buy me. The slave bugs her.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Away, away, you're a wag, is your breath sweet, let me smell, you are very forward, pray turn, and let's see your price,He kisses her.here soldier, take your money.

sp.speaker: 1 soldier
sp.p: Thank you, may his back never fail you.

sp.speaker: Pimp.
sp.p: Faith, you are too dear. — stay, here comes the prince Bragadine, the viceroy's son.

sp.speaker: Bragad.
sp.p: How now, soldier, what famous prize is that?

sp.speaker: 1 soldier
sp.p: A Greek sir, a virgin.

sp.speaker: Bragad.
sp.p: What's her price?

sp.speaker: 1 soldier
sp.p: Two thousand sestertia.

sp.speaker: Bragad.
sp.p: It's dear, and yet it's a proper wench.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: My sister not arrived yet at Baio? it's strange.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: No sir, not yet, but she has been expected these ten days.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: What crowd is that?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: The slave-mart is held today.

sp.speaker: Bragad.
sp.p: What stranger is that?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p:
Was that fellow drunk?
As Virgilius comes in, he meets Bragadine going out, they justle, and look scurtily at one another.
Virgilius spies Cicilia. and falls in love with her.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Either drunk or worse.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Is that excellent piece to be sold?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: She is not, who can buy her? or who dares set a price upon that beauty? Fairest, what country is (At this time) cursed with your absence, for sure 'tis perpetual night when you are thence.

sp.speaker: Cicilia.
sp.p: Greece, sir, is my country, more particulars I must not tell.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Fool's that we are, to call ourselves conquerors of Greece, when one slave, one handful of that earth, has power to conquer me, and lead me bound, even in my own country.

sp.speaker: Cicilia.
sp.p: It is not becoming your youth, nor fortune (How great soever ) to make a scorn of those miseries which chance throws upon the innocent.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: A strange curse find me when I scorn you; dare you not tell me what you were before this ruin?

sp.speaker: Cicilia.
sp.p: I must not, sir.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: And are there no statues fixed in the temples, or history, that preserves your story? must all but your beauty sink with this ruin?

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: Sir, if you will buy her, take her upon her price; if not,The soldier interrupts him. give others leave to bid.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Fool, thou canst not sell her, for thou knowest not how to value her, yet cozen thyself; what dost thou ask?

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: Two thousand sestertia.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Is that all?

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: All! yes.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: And is she free when that is paid?

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: Yes, if you please.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Madam, not to call you mine, but to have a power to appear yours, give me leave, with the loss of mine own, to find your freedom. Go fetch two thousand sestertia. — unbind her. Virgilius puts her chains upon his arm.

sp.speaker: Cicilia.
sp.p: What mean you, sir?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: They are proper here; and I beg you will not refuse (When honour consents) to release me.

sp.speaker: Cicilia.
sp.p: I hope my miseries will not beget ingratitude in me, for I confess, 'tis some joy in the midst of these troubles, to find that honour that shines throughout this act; and though my bonds be as new and strange to me as yourself, yet let me say, if there be a faulty thought that bids you hope to find a slave's heart here, you are deceived; for I would sooner sell myself to slavery, or, by a wound seek a freedom.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: By thyself, by thy angel self, I approach thee with thoughts as pure and as constant as those our vestals wait on the holy flame with; and but that I know you would scorn a sacrifice that's offered by profane hands, those attributes are given to the gods I'd kneel and pay to you.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Soldier, the prince would speak with you.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: Which is that fine thing you spoke of? Above in the window appears Paulina and the bawd.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: That that the stranger stands by.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: That stranger, knowest thou that stranger?

sp.speaker: Bawd,
sp.p: No, not I.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: Now by the sins of my youth, 'tis a godlike form! — why do they pull the woman so? The soldier returns, and lays hold on Cicilia.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: How now, unhand her villain, is she not free?

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: You have not paid your money, and I must not lose my market you talked, and another has gone through with the bargain.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Another, what other?

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: One that will find the way to her sex, before you'll come to kissing her hand: take her away.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Slave, dost thou glory in thy villainies? — there, now letVirgilius stabbs him. him that dares claim her follow me and take her.

sp.speaker: Cicilia.
sp.p: What have you done, sir?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Fairest, begun a justice I hope the gods will finish. The rest of the soldiers draw and call for help. Murder.

sp.speaker: Bragad.
sp.p: How, killed! whose act is this?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Mine, and I'll answer it; some one that knew him follow me, and take the money for this lady.

sp.speaker: Bragad.
sp.p: That woman I have paid for, and I will not quit my purchase; either yield her, or I shall force her.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: I know what 'tis command, but never yet heard that voice (Unless an oracle) that I would have obeyed when the speaker frowned, and thou lookest not like him whose voice is thunder.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p:
Gallant youth.
He lays hold of her.
He strikes him and 〈◊〉.
Bragadine and the soldiers draw.
They fight.
Enter soldiers armed.
Exeunt omnes.

sp.speaker: Bragad.
sp.p: I cannot talk, sir, but I shall take my own.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Touch her not, yet I have patience, let her alone. — nay, if you will be insolent, I'll punish it if I can.

sp.speaker: Bragad.
sp.p: Kill the dog.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: Hold sir, as you have any sense of honour, hold for shame, betray not thy fame so poorly as to let a slave share in thy revenge; this base odds calls thee coward, though thou conquerest.

sp.speaker: Bragad.
sp.p: Who made you a judge of mine honour?

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: So, I fear you'll find your treachery no guard.

sp.speaker: 1 soldier
sp.p: This way, this way he is gone, seize her and secure her to the prince's house, whilst we follow him.

div.head: Act. ii. scen. iii.
div.stage: Enter Virgilius, and the soldiers after him.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Villains, whither tends your rage?

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: To revenge: yield, or thou art dead.

sp.speaker: Paulina above.
sp.p: Slaves, leave to pursue that stranger, or I'll send those shall shake your wretched souls out of their cases.

sp.speaker: 2 soldier
sp.p: What's she?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: whate'er you are that thus have lent your pity to a stranger, in distress, may you never know what 'tis to want a pity.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: To buy a slave?

sp.speaker: 3 soldier
sp.p: Upon him, alive or dead, we'll have him.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Ha! the prince engaged, draw.

sp.speaker: Bragad.
sp.p: Hell upon you all, where were your mercenary swords when they should assist? 'sdeath, to let a single stranger, in mine own door, brave me, and none by, to kill the dog? who now is escaped, to brag that he snatched from Bragadine a slave that he bought and paid for.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: Sir, we could not prophesy, your highness would go out; and none called us; but for the slave, she is at home, and safe, the sailors brought her, and are now in pursuit of the stranger.

sp.speaker: Bragad.
sp.p: If she be safe, let's lose no time, but follow them, lest he escape, with his glories, which which way went they?

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: This way, sir.

div.head: Act. iii. Scen. i.
div.stage: Enter Virgilius, Facertes, and Minetes in rage, for the loss of Cicilia.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: How do you, sir?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Not well.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: What accident was this?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p:
Oh! Facertes, I have seen my fate, and I conjure thee by all our friendship, not to call me weak, nor dispute with my passion, but obey thy friend, and suddenly, or I am lost for ever; for her innocence, I fear, will be no guard against their power; and without impiety I may mistrust the gods, for they already have slept, and let her fall into misery; o, Facertes, I am a slave to a
slave, and to hers my fate is bound. And temples, not chains are due to her; and when thou seest her thou wilt forgive me this change, for she has a beauty against which thy honour must arm, else thy love will be no more a guard then was my resolution.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: All this for a slave!

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Oh! do not revile her; for when thou meetest her, thy wonder and repentance will make but one thought, and like me thou wilt be lost in a maze.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: This is strange.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: I confess it; yet when the world was innocent before the bloody sword taught her pride by conquest, and learned the thirsty wool to drink the purple dye, till it grew enriched with the far-fetched stains, such innocence and beauty as waits on her might anywhere have claimed a sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Sir, though I grant all these beauties, yet to me they bring like miseries to those the swift lightning leaves the wretched husbandman; who instead of full joys, reaps from those wounding fires naught but weighty griefs; yet I'll obey you, though in this chance I foresee my own despairs, to the little hopes I had of happiness. Farewell.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Why do you conclude so? must you of necessity be miserable, if I be happy? are my friends joys the less, 'cause mine are full?

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Pardon me, sir, if you find me troubled to see all my hopes withered, and those wounds you gave my suffering country now despairing of a cure.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: O friend! friend! has that word no power?

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Yes, and that makes me sleight my interest; for I am so accustomed to misfortune, 'tis almost natural to me: but when I think on whom you throw your fortune, youth and fame, I find a greater trouble as your friend, then as I am the lost Facertes; for you know not what she is; your love hunts thus in the dark, a slave, a thing set at sale for lust. Virg. offers to go away.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: That, that, Facertes makes me rage; and again by all that's powerful I conjure thee fly with me to her rescue, before such a ruin find her.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Virgilius, sir, Virgilius stay; I must obey him, or he's lost.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Draw thy sword then, and let me see thee plead with that against her enemies, as thou didst against me at Siracusa, and I'll conclude all hopes from that powerful argument.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Sir, I never used my arguments to spare my sword; nor was my tongue now drawn, because I meant that should sleep: see 'tis drawn, but in vain you hope a service from it, as yourself; and therefore stay here, while I fit you with a disguise.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Be speedy then. As Virg. and Minetes are going out they meet the bawd, Olympia.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: I shall, but pray retire a little, this place is too public, I'll return immediately.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: I'll stay at the corner. —

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: May I be bold?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: With whom?

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: With you, sir.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p:
Sir, your pardon.
He offers to go away, but she takes hold of him.
He offers her money.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: For what? I forgive thee.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Sir, I would beg.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Here, I'll prevent thee, if thou wilt let me go. —

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: No, sir, my business is no money; 'tis yourself must satisfy me.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Thou art mistaken sure, thy business was to my man.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: No, sir, I go upon no such errands. Did you not fight for a slave even now?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Yes, what of her?

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Are you he?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Yes, I tell thee.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Farewell then, till you are at leisure.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Prithee stay.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: No, sir, your man is busy.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Prithee excuse my trouble, which gave not ear to thee at first.

sp.speaker: Paulina above.
sp.p: That's he, why stays she so long to deliver her message? she is angry.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: For once I excuse; you and look hereafter you entertain a woman with more: but to the business; the slave you wot of — (O! that eye of yours) there lies a wag in't that will make a world of mischief,) you know not who it hath struck, pray heaven I get not a wound.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Nay, to your story, good mother, and leave this wandering.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Mother? whose mother, goodman boy? I am a maid.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: You mistake me, I meant, mother of my joys, and so you will be if you can lay by this youthful fire that makes you thus subject to choler, and proceed with your story.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Yes, yes, do you jeer me?

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: I can endure no longer; sir, whate'er you are, take my faith for your safety, and make this house your sanctuary; something concerning that slave I would deliver to you.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Are you there, hell and mischief find you.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Madam, who ere you are that offers this charity to a stranger; know, I dare enter though I saw my ruin in the door. For fear I never found his pale den yet, though I have oft trod those paths that led both to dangers and to death; and I should scorn myself, could I apprehend him now where beauty has the guard. Which way do your commands guide me?

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: That door.

div.stage: [ex. Virg. and his man, and paul. from above.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p:
Now a public pox go with thee, that thy face may serve thee in no stead; malicious villain, to call up my dead fears that had wont to tell me I had lost my time; proud scurvy fellow, to put me thus in despair; and if he had any good nature, he would have offered me a kindness, in courtesy to have comforted
me; I shall not eat today; had he but called me whore, yet it had been tolerable, for that carries youth with it. But old mother? Rascal, none of thy mother. But I'll be revenged.

div.head: Act. iii. Scen. ii.
div.stage: The lieutenant appears under the hanging, and Nigro by him groaning.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Crabb, Crabb.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.p: Oh!

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Crabb, what's that groans?

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.p: Help, help for charity, more wounds, or remedy.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Ha! what's that? help, where am I? 'tis a man making his will, I'll be his heir, ha! what's here? A man wounded? this is that rogue, Crabb; he has robbed him, and laid him here to make me accessary.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.p: Help, if you have charity.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: With all my heart, and prithee, do me the favour to live till we come to my quarter.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.p: If I do, I shall discover something pleasing to you.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Marry, I'll carry thee, for thy testimony, there is nothing else in this case can save me. — you are no rogue, Crabb! Who did this?

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.p: Not he.

sp.speaker: Crabb.
sp.p: That's good evidence for me.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Nor I, by this hand, you must quit me, while you can speak.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.p: I acquit you both.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Witness, witness, Crabb.

sp.speaker: Crabb.
sp.p: Where did you find him?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Find him? by this hand, he found me and lay down by me, as I was asleep.

sp.speaker: Crabb.
sp.p: Why, faith he is going a long journey, and came to take you with him, thou art good company; but to leave this discourse, take my business: our captain would have you go visit the sick party, and see whether he will be persuaded yet or no to die.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: I hate to see the rogue; I have such battles in my head, since morning, yet I'll go, while I am near him, and take you charge of this old man in the mean time, and see him carefully dressed.

sp.speaker: Crabb.
sp.p: So, lean upon me, what rogues were these to use an old man thus?

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Within lieutenant
sp.p: Where is this old fellow, is he alive still?

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Bring him out, to take a little fresh air.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: Is he come again? why did you let him in? he'll be a lasting a tedious affliction to me.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: How now? how is't, how is't man?

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: Neither live nor die in peace?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Yes, die in as much peace as you can.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: When my time comes; but I hope a man may have leave to live out his days; my physician says, I may escape yet.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Your physician's an ass, and you give him too great fees.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: He tells me I may escape this fit, if I can recover mine enemies; for he assures me, my greatest danger is my heir.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Does he say so? I cry him mercy then, he is a knowing man, I believe so too: and you may, perhaps, at a great charge, recover; but, in my opinion, you had better die, and take our prayers with you; for to recover would but incense the captain, and lose your friends.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: Sure my captain would be loath to lose me; he ever loved me.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Why I; and yet you refuse him to die, and think much to hasten your journey a day or two, for his sake.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: Alas, I would be glad to serve my captain in any thing that lies in my power, I'll pray for him, and I hope he will excuse me for desiring to live, and serve him.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: You may flatter yourself, but I'll assure you, he takes it very ill at your hands, that you, of all his company, should refuse him such a kindness, nay, not to appear willing to do it, if it were in your power; but thus, with an unnecessary charge, endeavour to live, crossing the disease that would be friend him.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: Alas, I do nothing to cross it, I do but suffer.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Will you promise me that, and let the disease alone, it will be some satisfaction to him, and to us that are your friends, to see that you endeavour to satisfy him.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: That I'll promise you: and from henceforth I'll seek no remedy, but put myself into the hand of his friend, as you called it.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Then you shall see how carefully we'll provide for you; for I hope you do not think, that we or he desires this, because he is loath you should live two or three days; for what were that to him, but that he is to go out then; and the next captain will be your heir.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: Alas, sir, how can I help it? 'tis against my will, if anybody be my heir.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Well, look you keep covenants, and endeavour to die finely; banish your physician and jelly-broth, I'll provide noises to keep you waking. Crabb, provide two drums to beat here their watch a piece; and do you hear, beware of a good diet.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: As you have charity, let me rest, those drums are daggers to me.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Nay, you'll be unreasonable again, I see it.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: O misery of wealth!

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: I confess, my first thoughts were like myself, faulty: but now I have gained by losing a desire, and I shall serve you faithfully in your love.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: All my fears are, that he will violate her.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: He dares not do it, I have conjured him from it, and when it may serve you, I'll boast my power, though purchased with a fault; and though your virtue secured you from that power, yet where sin has interest, mine never wanted a command; and I know he dares not stand those frowns which your goodness melted into tears.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: No more, when we have sighed for our faults, they vanish with the same air; yet I fear him, though I believe your power great; for he that dares be a coward will stop at no wickedness within his reach.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: I made him ashamed of that base act, and vow not to pursue you; yet I counsel you not to stay long in this town after you have her.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: What time did he appoint to bring her?

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: He parted hence just as you entered, with a promise immediately to return; and if he should find you here, I am afraid it would prejudice my power to serve you; else I should rejoice to be seen where so much honour dwells.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Your civilities and mercies, madam, showed to me, a stranger, I shall with a grateful mention acknowledge through the world; pray, what time will your commands enjoin my return?

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: It will not be safe, sir, to come at all; but pray be pleased to send a friend after dinner, and you shall have notice of his first departure, what time that will be; yet I know not, for I am so miserable, I cannot now be good, but with a wicked pretence, there is another door leads into a street less frequented than that you entered at.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Which way must I take to find it?

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: I'll guide you, sir.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: It is well, happy discovery; now I shall be revenged at full; was it not enough to have his pride throw a scorn upon me, but she must revile me too? Fool, in scorn thou called'st me mother, and thou shalt find the malice of an old woman here, that in her years, not desires, is aged; one that has lost that mercy-kindling fire which should plead for thee, and prevent that youthful malice, whose fruitful mischiefs shall make thee old in miseries; nor shall religion, nor beauties of thy youth, protect thee from that dangerous hate thy scorns have bred, till thy despairs have taught thee how killing a malice hot lust in cold limbs pursues. — the plot is here; jealousy, 'tis thou must work my ends, with that I'll assault the prince, and from the wounds it brings, reap my revenge; for jealousy, though it leave no scars behind, yet with desperate wounds it assails the mind.

sp.speaker: Facer.
sp.p:
This, by the description of the house, should be the place that holds my miseries: from what a second height of happiness am I fallen? Virgilius is young, and I fear, the guilt of having so many ways ruined me will make him hate me for being innocent; but I am resolved, and will rather fall by misfortunes than faults; and, for the excellent Sophia's sake, will serve him till he blush to command me. And when his passion is over, he shall confess, I can bear a loss better than he rule a victory. But what areEnter bragadine, Cicilia, and others. these? I must stand close. 'tis he, and that (By her habit) the slave our fortune's bow to: gods! was it not enough we fell a sacrifice to the Julian deity, and filled the triumph of that monarchy, that thus your rage pursues us? must all our fortunes be slaved to a slave, and bound with chains to chains. — ye gods! what
They pass by, Cicilia looks sadly on the ground, Facertes knows her.
She looks about upon Facertes all the way, till she goes off. Exeunt all but Facertes.do I see? Cicilia my sister?

sp.speaker: Cicilia.
sp.p: What said he?

sp.speaker: Facer.
sp.p: It is she. Blessed chance. Ye powers of Sicily, your hands are visible in this; forgive Facertes that confesses, men may the metal bring, but the form of our happiness the gods appoint us still.

div.head: Act. iv. scen. i.
div.stage: Enter the captain, lieutenant, Crabb, and Cilius.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Faith, sir, hanging of 'em will be but a hindrance to yourself; 'tis true they are rogues, and have no conscience, yet, at the worst, they are so much horse.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I say, hang 'em.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: I say so to, if hanging were a punishment, but to them 'tis freedom.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: No more dispute, but hang 'em slaves, to rob me now when I am quitting my command.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Well, they shall be hanged, but they shall stay till they be hungry, and have digested their full cups; if if you hang 'em now they're full and drunk, they'll think they have but swallowed awry or surfeited; and instead of being punished, the rogues will go out like senators.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: The old soldier confesses they were of Sicily, and of quality, and now sent for a present to the emperor, and that was the viceroy that was slain, he would have yielded good money.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: And one of the slaves confessed the woman was of such a beauty, and so ravishing, that they fought who should purchase her.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: There had been a fellow for your bird at home, two such fleas would suck a man to death.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Come, talk no more on't now, there's no remedy, go prepare those others for the mart, and see the slaves hanged: what? how do they look? is't a handsome freight?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Yes faith, sir, there will be a jolly number with the boys; and I would advise you, sir, not to show the women and the boys together, for they'll spoil the sale of the wenches.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Why then we'll sell the women first.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: Who these Sicilians should be, troubles me; if we made haste we might hear some news of her at Naples, for there they were sold.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Tomorrow we'll provide for the journey; lieutenant, see every thing in readiness.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: Something I'll do, to give one of them her freedom, as sure as you count her, though you refuse to sell it me.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Is the old fellow dead?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: No. But I have prevailed with him to quit his physic; and I am certain, he hath neither eat, nor drank, nor slept since.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Let's go see him.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Cilius is melancholy for the wench.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: No matter, I'd rather he were angry then lost; for though he know not his own value, I know it, come let's leave him.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: 'Tis not treachery to save the innocent. I'll do it.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: I'll sacrifice to fortune, she shall henceforth be the power I'll worship, to whom I owe this unexpected joy, she has tamed lust, till it was love, and lent only so much sin to the wicked as served me; and I that could not stand safe among the innocent, find a security among the wicked. — Facertes?

sp.speaker: Facer.
sp.p: Look here, ere I speak my news, does not Virgilius see a joy break like a glory round about my brow, to distinguish this my first happy hour?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: It is thy friendship that sympathizes mine. O Facertes, such an accident hath happened since thou leftest me, that I must wink, rub mine eyes, and call all my reason to secure me I do not dream.

sp.speaker: Facer.
sp.p: whate'er your joys are, they must give place to mine; for they are yours and mine, not as we are barely friends, but from the assurance that we shall ever be so.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: I confess thy joys bring to me a greater comfort than mine own, prithee give them a name.

sp.speaker: Facer.
sp.p: Do you believe a second view of her you have seen will not render her common to your eye? or, to possess those beauties make them cheap in your opinion? if not, I am happier than you, and whenever you enjoy your wishes I reap mine.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: By our friendship I beg this blessing from you, yet this is not strange where friendship is not strange.

sp.speaker: Facer.
sp.p: The slave is my sister but by what accident fallen to this misery I know not.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Who? the famed Cicilia?

sp.speaker: Facer.
sp.p: She. Never free till now, and this fall was but to raise her to a greater height.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Then I mistrust my joys; they grow too near a height to continue.

sp.speaker: Facer.
sp.p: Are you sorry, sir, it is she? Then it was not chance changed our first design; is she less worthy of your love now then before? I should be sorry to find your ignorance of what you valued preferred before your knowledge; or is there some second face you have met hath blotted out this too?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: O Facertes, why art thou so subject to mistake thy friend?

sp.speaker: Facer.
sp.p: If I mistake, why are you so sad? I found you full of joy.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Not that 'tis she makes me sad; for, witness heaven, I have no wish beyond her,; her eye circles my heaven, and till I have place in her esteem I am in hell.

sp.speaker: Facer.
sp.p: Why should that suspicion make you sad, considering you are, and what you have done for her? Besides, am not I here with a brother and a friend's interest?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Who I am, that, Facertes, begets my despairs; for that 'tis I is all arguments against me; will she not, when she sees me, call to mind a father (Whose piety the gods spared) fallen, to satisfy the lust of empire? are not yet the wounds bleeding, and the yoke still laid upon her suffering country? Now judge what can be said of hope, when this pleads against me. O Facertes, thou hast not read thy sister, thou lookest with a brother's eye, this fate I prophesy from one sight; and let me tell thee, if she be worthy of Virgilius she must hate Virgilius.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Sir, I confess my friendship made me oversee what I was reconciled to, and now I begin to fear; yet when she shall know how I have been obliged, that mercy I found from the fair Sophia, her honour will guide her to return Virgilius; for though it makes her to resent your injuries, yet she must be just to her, and then her gratitude secures you; for though she has honour, yet she has woman too, and mercy is as great an attribute as justice, and she cannot be always angry.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Against any thing but her frown I could arm, and this night be happy. For by a strange chance I have found a way (If she consent) to release her.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: By what accident came you to that power? have you seen her since?

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: No, but this place is too public; let's retire, and you shall know all; and when I would my sister know, I'll read her through thy observations; but here let thy interest give way to my love.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: I shall obey, sir.

div.head: Act. iv. scen. iii.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: My thoughts can find no rest; love, wilt thou not quit me in prison? art thou covetous of my chains too? Fool! hast thou not miseries enough of thine own? And yet I ought not to revile him; for he that hath filled my heart is full of honour, and could he guess my fate, I know he would quit a crown, as a burden, and seek a freedom in these chains. The gods are just, to let me fall into these miseries, that we may taste what 'tis our ambition imposes upon others, guilty only as I was, by being too weak. — who's that? come in; prisoners keepOne knocks.no doors.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: Madam, I come to tell you, our captain has refused to sell me your freedom, and tomorrow is the mart at Naples; but if you dare trust him, whose misfortunes have made him appear your enemy, I'll gauge a life to save your honour, and give you freedom. The plot is already laid, and those that were taken with you I have already acquainted with it.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Sir, I shall willingly obey any directions, without a thought of fear, for sure there's no condition below this.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p: I will not now dispute this misfortune, but remedy it if I can; know, tomorrow (Lest the accident surprise you ere we put to sea) I have so ordered, that all the slaves that row in the galley shall be loose, the captain is my creature, and myself will still wait upon you, and be your guard; but be pleased to sit still when the word is given, and let us work your fate; but once free, command Cilius where you please, your friends too shall privately be armed.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Sir, what to say in return of this, I know not, and if you that can be thus gallant, thus good, cannot likewise from that honour that directs you now, find a reward, I fear you will lose this good deed.

sp.speaker: Cil.
