sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: No, no, only borrow your breeches; for look, sir, what need you such gay things as these now when you are going to lie alone in the dark?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Oh! misery of miseries!

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: Ha, ha, this revenge is better than long life.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: O inhumane slave! A noise within.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: What noise is that?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: 'Tis vengeance, slave; I will make thee curse thyself.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: Silence, my small friend, or else I have a plaster of coldHe draws his dagger.iron, hight a dagger; by this hilt, I will apply the point to your side, if you breathe one loud syllable more; marry, if you will, curse inwardly; 'twas my own case once, and I forgive it.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Patience, o patience.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: Ay, ay, come when she will, you will have use of her; this noise draws this way, I must pluck him into the wood, and then I'll cut his throat; you had best bethink you of some odd prayer, for it must be so. He pulls him by the heels off the stage.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: Murder, villain, dog.

sp.speaker: Tull.
sp.p: Come, come along, sir; why should you grudge to die when I am to be your heir?

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.p: O misery, misery of miseries, is there no revenge?

div.head: Act. v. scen. vi.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Whence grew this sudden alarm?

sp.speaker: 1 Rom.
sp.p: I fear, from the discovery of the plot; if it be so, we are lost for ever.

div.stage: Enter captain and Nigro, after them Facertes, Cicilia and Paulina.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Lead them in and bind 'em, and some one run for a surgeon.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.p: What are these, sir?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I know not; pray heaven they be worth the purchase: we have paid dear for 'em; prithee help me off.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Facertes! 'tis he, and women in his company; I will not suspect him she that is jealous; sets a cheap rate upon herself; for if he be worthy of such a pain as jealousy, he cannot be so faulty as to deserve it.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: I am amazed, 'tis the Princess Sophia.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: Sophia?

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p:
What miseries do I see, madam, to add to mine own afflictions; I never thought I should have lived to see the day
wherein I should have grieved to have met the fair Sophia.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Why are you afflicted to meet me now?

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Oh! madam, my love begets my sorrows; for what shall I think? my thoughts are divided, to meet your highness, where licence sows, and sin reaps; here, where rage fetches her fire, and murder baths his bloody hands; and unsensibly recounts in security the treacherous stabs.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Say this guilt be here, must I be subject to the infection?

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: I do not think you are guilty, yet my fears tells me, where tired lust retires to pant, such beauties as adore the fair Sophia, must kindle fresh fires.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Why do you wound me thus with your suspicion, and rob me of the joy I had to see you? 'tis not kindly done to add such a pain to my misfortune; had you fallen into the power of our sex, though sold to sin; like these, I could have died sooner than have injured you so as to think you would-out live your honour; and when you are just to me, you will not believe I prize mine so little as to sell it for a shamed life.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Oh! divinest, pardon my love, whose fears still apprehend the worst.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: Madam, let the impatiency that begets this rudeness excuse it while I profess myself, by all ties, yours; for though, till now, a stranger to you; yet I am one that owes your civil mentions a life, which your mercy lent this unfortunate brother.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Speak, Facertes, is this the Princess, Cicilia?

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: This was; but what she is now the gods only know. They embrace and weep.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Oh! madam, in love and miseries we are become one; and my whole stock of tears I would waste here, could that wash off my country's crime, or remove the stain.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: I have forgotten my part of them; so new and so strange are the favours you and your gallant brother have loaded us with, that his dangers now are all my fears.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: My brother! where is he? have you seen him?

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: Yes, madam; and I fear he is at this instant hunting, with certain danger, our uncertain safety.

div.stage: Enter Nigro, captain, and a soldier.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Ha! the same prisoners that were stole, and sold at Naples.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: Upon my life, sir, 'tis true.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.p: 'Tis, 'tis she, and the prince Facertes too. Nig. kneels, and they embrace him.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: The honoured Nigro?

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: Alive? o ye gods! This day is full of your hands; and all is like you (Wonder.)

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Rise, why do you kneel? o, lay that aged head here; where are we? what strange place is this the Sicilian deity is run to hide herself in?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Though I do not know thy face; yet to Facertes name, here kneels a subject, and one of those your dead father called faithful, my name Terresius.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.p: Terresius?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Yes Terresius, Nigro, that with him from the same battle, when you fled with this gallant prince, bore away the hopeful Lucius; we have run strange fortunes since; but I durst not tell him what he was, lest his fiery nature should have pulled on a certain ruin.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: My brother Lucius living?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Yes, sir; and that, I hope, will expiate the fault my ignorance this day committed.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: Where is he, sir?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I left him pursuing the victory, but I'll haste and tell him this news it will stay his rage, which else may pursue his own ruin upon his friends.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: For heaven's sake haste, lest he and the prince Virgilius meet; for either of their conquests brings my ruin.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Let me accompany you.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I dare not, sir, for yet the soldiers know you not; and their mistake of duty to me may bring on a sad consequence.

sp.speaker: Nig.
sp.p: For heaven's sake lose no time, but haste to prevent this danger.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I'll send an officer, sir, to guard you; and then with safety you may come but till then; I beseech you stir not.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Pray, madam, what blessed chance brought my brother to have the power to serve you.

sp.speaker: Facert.
sp.p: Defer that story till a fitter time, and haste now to the saving of your brother.

sp.speaker: Cicil.
sp.p: Pray lead the way, lest our ceremony hinder our charity.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: If you'll give me leave to command, I'll obey; you must not refuse me your hand; o! that the gods had made our countries join thus in peace.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: They cannot escape; I have fired their galley, and mine lies lose, in wait for any that shall come to their aid. Miserable Virgilius! unfortunate that I am, preserved only to a greater loss; this way a soldier (Whose dying words could only guide me) said they took; I'll hunt them to their den but I'll find the monsters.

div.head: Act. v. scen. viii.

sp.speaker: Cil.
sp.p:
The galley fired, and the lieutenant slain; hell upon him, he has crossed all my designs; fate thou art fate
still, but whither just or no thus to strike against the intentions of the honest, the gods be judge; all my hopes are sunk; that excellent maid is lost too, and I shall appear guilty and treacherous to her; but if I find the cursed incendiary, with his hateful blood I'll quench the flame: take that path, if you find him, call.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: Sir, this is he. As the soldier goes out, he calls Virgilius.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: This, by description, should be him I seek.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: What art thou, that walk'st with such confidence in these forbidden woods? Know, thou hast kindled a fire nothing but thy blood shall extinguish.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Unless thou wilt fall too, and make one in that ruin, I counsel thee immediately to deliver (Without repetition) those whom thy treacherous odds have ravished hence.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: I will not revile thee, because I mean to fight with thee; yet I would gladly know whence thou art, that hopest with thy threats to wash off this glorious colour, and shake those fruits that conquest gave a growth to here.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Rome claims my birth.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: So it does of him I hate more than the loathed issues of the earth.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: What art thou, that dar'st avow such a hatred of a roman to a Roman's face?

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: I am of Sicily, the unfortunate subject of your rage.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: So is she I prefer equal with the gods; yet her interest in the nation shall not protect thee that art so base as to make spoil of thine own nest.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: You'll find words of no force here, and thou lookest as if thou wouldst not yield upon entreaty.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Nor canst thou conquer me, when I fight in her cause, though thou takest the odds of his sword.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: His? he dares not strike, where he sees my sword drawn upon a single opposite.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: You will not deliver these ladies then?

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: I'll give thee all my glory first; yet I know thou art the author of all those miseries that shall succeed; for hadst not thou burned my galley, I had decreed their safety, but now thou hast sold them to perpetual slavery.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: The guilty never want excuses, but I shall punish both those falsehoods.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: Soldier, upon your life stir not a foot to my rescue, I scorn to live upon charity.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: I'll talk no longer, their freedoms or thy sword; for my vows are writ in heaven, never to sheathe this sword till I found them or a grave.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: One of them I'll guide you to, or miss my aim. — fortune,They fight, and are both wounded. Cilius staggers. hast thou decreed that I shall blush to death? Loose where my love and country's genius both strike? If thou beest a deity save my honour.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p:
Will you yield, or try a farther fate?
They fight, and in the close Vigilius takes bold of Cilius' sword.
They struggle upon the ground, a noise within crying follow follow.
Virgil. and Cilius rise together and part.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: No, roman, we may be overcome, but we scorn to yield.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Ask thy life, or thou art dead.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: No, when thou canst give it, 'tis not worth asking.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Then 'tis not worth taking.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: What noise is that?

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: I know not, sir.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: Draw, and kill any thing that offers to rescue me; for when Cilius cannot stand alone in this cause, let him fall for ever.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: I would thou hadst not deserved my sword.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.p: Stand, he that advances a step as friend or enemy, till they have done, shall kill or die.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: How now, sirrah? Cilius, if the name of Facertes or Cicilia have a power, you'll cease to be an enemy there. They go to them.

sp.speaker: Nigro.
sp.p: Or if the brave Virgilius be satisfied with shedding of Sicilian blood, he will now spare the lost Lucius, and reconcile himselfThey part 'em, they gaze upon one another.to that brother enemy.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Prince Lucius!

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: Virgilius!

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: Yes, sir, Virgilius, and there are coming those whose interest in either will quickly clear this doubt.

div.stage: Enter Facertes, Cicilia, Sophia, Paulina, and Romans.

sp.speaker: Facer.
sp.p: Sir, by the name of brother; I conjure you to defer this hate till you have heard us speak.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: And if I have a sister's interest it will disarm Virgilius.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Sister? what strange accident brought thee hither? — madam, will you pardon that uncivil joy that passed you to findTo Cicilia.a sister?

sp.speaker: Cicilia.
sp.p: Yes, sir, if you'll help me find a friend to Virgilius, and a lost brother to Cicilia.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: Terresius, unfold this riddle, amazement yet withholds my sword, and has almost bound my reason; what means this shuffling of Facertes, Cicilia, Virgilius and Lucius together? Those names, and this dearness, what means it?

sp.speaker: Nigro.
sp.p: Dare you trust me?

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: The honoured Nigro.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Or me, whose faith you have bought; and give us leave to reconcile this wonder?

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: Madam, I am all your slave, and when your hand deals it destruction shall fall on Cilius unresisted.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Dare you show your breast? 'tis all I beg.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: Yes, fair one, and every thought of it shall to you be visible.

sp.speaker: Nigro.
sp.p: Here, here, 'tis a thousand witnesses to prove the lost Lucius.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: 'Tis so, and upon his knees Teresius begs his pardon for keeping this secret so long from you; but now it comes accompanied with many blessings; see here your brother, the prince Facertes, and the excellent Cicilia, whose loves have been by fate appointed to restore our country to her long-lost liberty.

sp.speaker: Facer.
sp.p: And if Lucius finds a part of this joy, let him with friendly arms embrace Virgilius, who is now a brother, and ever a friend.

sp.speaker: Cicilia.
sp.p: Dare you from my hand take him?

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: That I have been thus long silent, let the wonder you have begotten plead for me; and, sir, that we durst be enemies shouldThey embracebe no stop to that faith, which confirms we dare be friends.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Sir, your last act assures Virgilius, who cannot believe he is safe till you embrace him; for I know, such an enemy as prince Lucius reconciled will prove a conquering friend.

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: The gods make this friendship as lasting as 'tis strange.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: Madam, doth this change bring no hope to Lucius? must he still be the despairing Cilius? dare you not yet tell me who youThey embrace again.are?

sp.speaker: Sophia.
sp.p: Yes, my name's Sophia.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: Ha, the Princess Sophia?

sp.speaker: Facer.
sp.p: Yes, Lucius: but why is my brother sad? does he mourn my interest there?

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: No, sir, I neither mourn yours there, nor the excellent Sophia's here; but I am hunting out a way to bear myself like Lucius in this great day; your hand, madam, — here Facertes from fate receive this jewel, 'tis a wealth I cannot hope to possess, but by being unworthy of it; and it shall be Lucius his glory to say, to keep his fame, he gave that away.

sp.speaker: Nigro.
sp.p: Let no replies defer the joys that attend this day.

sp.speaker: Cilius.
sp.p: To the temple then, while with healing sacrifice Virgilius loads the altars.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: I shall follow, if Lucius will lead the way. Thus blessed, and thus embraced, more a god than they.
sp.l: Yet lest we leave our enemies behind,
Let's know how these our judges stand inclined.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
